meanings.def: to make a hole in the ground or to move soil from one place to another using your hands, a tool or a machine
examples: I think I'll do some digging in the garden.
dig + adv./prep. They dug deeper and deeper but still found nothing.
We could only dig down a few feet.
dig for something to dig for gold/treasure
dig something to dig a hole/trench/grave
(British English) I've been digging the garden.
dig something + adv./prep. They had obviously dug special tunnels beneath the city.
The present entrance was dug through the soft limestone.
They were digging for buried treasure.
We found ourselves digging through solid clay.
We'll have to dig deep to get at the roots.
a freshly dug grave
digging the foundations of a new hotel

meanings.def: to remove something from the ground with a tool
examples: I'll dig some potatoes for lunch.

meanings.def: to search in something in order to find an object in something
examples: I dug around in my bag for a pen.

meanings.def: to approve of or like something very much
to search for information in a careful and detailed way
examples: You'll need to dig deep into the records to find the figures you want.

meanings.def: to try hard to provide the money, equipment, etc. that is needed
examples: We're asking you to dig deep for the earthquake victims.

meanings.def: to discover and reveal information about somebody that could damage them
examples: They hired private investigators to dig up dirt on their political opponents.
She has come to dig the dirt on her old rival.

meanings.def: to refuse to do something or to change your mind about something
examples: They dug in their heels and would not lower the price.

meanings.def: to spend a lot of your own money on something
to push your finger or your elbow into somebody’s side, especially to attract their attention
to do something that will have very harmful results for you
to get yourself into a bad situation that will be very difficult to get out of

idioms.def: to search for information in a careful and detailed way
examples: You'll need to dig deep into the records to find the figures you want.
We're asking you to dig deep for the earthquake victims.

idioms.idiom: dig the dirt | dig up dirt (on somebody)
idioms.def: to discover and reveal information about somebody that could damage them
examples: They hired private investigators to dig up dirt on their political opponents.
She has come to dig the dirt on her old rival.

idioms.def: to refuse to do something or to change your mind about something
examples: They dug in their heels and would not lower the price.

idioms.idiom: dig (deep) in/into your pocket(s), savings, etc.
idioms.def: to spend a lot of your own money on something
to push your finger or your elbow into somebody’s side, especially to attract their attention

idioms.idiom: dig your own grave | dig a grave for yourself
idioms.def: to do something that will have very harmful results for you
to get yourself into a bad situation that will be very difficult to get out of

related: dig (deep) in/into your pocket(s), savings, etc.

meanings.def: a small push with your finger or elbow
examples: She gave him a dig in the ribs.

meanings.def: a remark that is intended to annoy or upset somebody
examples: He kept making sly little digs at me.
to have a dig at somebody/something
I resisted the temptation to get in a sly dig at Fred.
They were having a little dig at her about the way she tells everybody else what to do.

meanings.def: an occasion when an organized group of people dig in the ground to discover old buildings or objects, in order to find out more about their history
examples: to go on a dig
an archaeological dig
I went on a dig over the summer.
The dig revealed the site of a Roman villa.
